citeinfo.origin: Federal Highway Administration, Office of Intermodal and Statewide Programs (HEPS-20)
citeinfo.title: National Highway Network Nodes
citeinfo.othercit: National Highway Planning Network Version 3.0 Machine Readable Data Files

descript.abstract: The National Highway Planning Network is a comprehensive network database of the nation's major highway system. It consists of over 400,000 miles of the nation's highways comprised of Rural Arterials, Urban Principal Arterials and all National Highway System routes. The data set covers the 48 contiguous States plus the District of Columbia, Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico. The nominal scale of the data set is 1:100,000 with a maximal positional error of ?80 meters.
descript.purpose: Transportation, regional planning analysis using GIS

idinfo.useconst: The NHPN Version 3.0 database, or any portion thereof, can be freely distributed as long as this metadata entry is included with each Distribution. The original metadata entry cannot be modified or Deleted from any data transfer. For Non-commercial use only.

cntorgp.cntorg: The Federal Highway Administration. Office of Intermodal and Statewide Programs, HEPS-20

cntinfo.cntinst: Between hours of 9 am and 3 p.m. Eastern Standard Time.

idinfo.datacred: The NHPN Version 3.0 database was created on behalf of FHWA by members of the Geographic Information Systems Laboratory, Systems Development Institute, The University of Tennessee, Knoxville.

citeinfo.title: National Highway Network
citeinfo.othercit: National Highway Planning Network Version 3.0 Machine Readable Data Files

attracc.attraccr: The accuracy of the fields FCLASS and STRAHNET from the description section of the line shapefile is consistent with State supplied information for the years 1992 and 1993. The accuracy of the fields MILES, KM, SIGN1, and NHS from the description section of the line shapefile is consistent with State supplied information for the years 1992 through 2001. All other attributes in the description of the link table are unverified.

dataqual.logic: All node and link topological relationships and uniqueness of entity IDs are verified by computer algorithm.
dataqual.complete: The complete urban principal arterial system and arterials in rural areas as reported to FHWA by December 1992 are inventoried in the database. The complete National Highway System is as reported to the FHWA by September 2000. Functional classes below arterial vary on a State by State basis.

horizpa.horizpar: The elements of the NHPN have been conflated to the 1:100,000 DLG-3 data set which maintains a nominal accuracy of at least +/-80 meters. Where new roads have been added which are not in the DLG-3 database link alignments have been digitized or converted from digital sources acquired from State DOTs with a map scale of at least 1:100,000.

srcinfo.srccontr: Road alignments for rural and urban highways.

citeinfo.origin: State supplied digital and map data

srcinfo.srccontr: Alignments and attributes for urban highways. Sign route and function class attributes for principal arterial system.

citeinfo.origin: State supplied digital and map data

srcinfo.srccontr: Alignments, sign route NHS classification for National Highway System.

citeinfo.origin: State supplied digital and map data

srcinfo.srccontr: Alignment, shape and location of ramp features

procstep.procdesc: The original shape file was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.
Conflation of NHPN V1 to DLG-3 road alignments using R-MATCH software developed by the Geographic Information Systems Group, University of Tennessee.
Digitizing and conversion of state supplied digital and map data. Line work geodetically controlled to match DLG-3 line work.
Integration of conflated version of NHPN V1 and assimilated State Data into a comprehensive topologically integrated network database. States edgematched and NHS attributes verified.
Integration of supplemental State Data into the NHPN V2. NHS attributes verified.
Integration of supplemental State data used for LRS attribute information.
Integration of intermodal connector links into the NHPN V2. States edgematched and NHS attributes verified.
Attachment of a Linear Referencing System to the NHPN V2. State Data used for LRS attribute information.

Integration of Ramp Group Cordon Boundary nodes into the NHPN for future addition of ramp group features. States edgematched, NHS attributes verified, and national LRSKEY added to facilitate a national route system.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypds: Federal Highway Administration, Office of Intermodal and Statewide Programs, HEPS-20

attr.attrdef: The VERSION is a 2-digit number that will be incremented for all records in the database whenever a new release is distributed. In this release the value is 03
County FIPS Code (must be combined with State FIPS Code for a unique ID)

Three digit HPMS Urbanized Area code for the Adjusted Urbanized Area in which the node lies. A value of 0 indicates the node is outside any HPMS Adjusted Urbanized Areas. Nodes which lie on the boundary of an Urbanized Area will have a LGURB value of Zero

The Source Flag is used to ideFive digit CENSUS Adjusted Small Urban Area code for cities under 50,000 population in 1990. A value of 0 indicates the node is outside any Adjusted Small Urban Area. Nodes which lie on the boundary of a small urban area will have a SMURB value of zero.
The BNDRY Flag is used to identify nodes which lie on the boundary of logical polygons maintained within NHPN.

attrvai.attrvae: The values for BNDRY are additive and can be used to describe a node which lies on the border of more than one boundary. For example a node at a State border will also be a county border node and will therefore, have a value of 1 + 10 = 11. Similarly a node which lies on the boundary of an Urbanized Area and a small urban area will have a BNDRY value of 4 + 2 = 6. If it were also a county boundary it would have a value of 1 + 2 + 4 = 7.

attr.attrdef: The SHAPE attribute is a data attribute inherent to the ESRI shapefile format.

edom.edomvd: A "point" represents a single location, usually identified by longitude-latitude, on the earth's surface.
